column2: Though while all channels's security comes from unanimity, not all unanimous systems are channels, eg. RANDAO
What are your priors for this, and what evidence has caused you to update those priors?
Counter-proposal: disregard this, channels are in fact defined by a unanimity requirement.
If it's not unanimous it's not a channel, it's a sidechain :)

8. Because the Cuban population has been self-selectively divided in this way, over the course of multiple generations.
7. And a lot of Cubans in Cuba do feel scared and vulnerable for exactly this reason. They know they don't have skills or drive to compete.
6. I once saw a cartoon on Cuban TV that basically said: "If those Miami Cubans come back, they're going to toss you out on the street."
5. Castro also cultivated fear among the risk-averse who stayed, that they'd be cast aside if their more ambitious relations ever returned.
4. Castro exploited the family feelings of the capable and ambitious who left to economically support the more biddable who stayed.
3. The risk-averse, the cautious, the fearful - they stayed. And were that much easier to keep in line.
2. The most ambitious and capable, the ones most likely to be dissatisfied and cause him trouble, were all but encouraged to leave.
1. Castro was very smart: he made it difficult but hardly impossible to leave Cuba. By doing so, he sorted Cubans into two groups.
No matter how much "reform" took place (precious little), Cuba could never truly turn the page until he was dead. Maybe it can now.
For Cubans born after 1959, even those who hated him, Castro was the ever-present patriarch, an overarching presence in their lives.
5. His sister was a regime loyalist, red to the core. But the whole family relied on money and gifts he sent them from the US.
4. Sitting in that Havana hotel lobby, knowing we were watched, so many things we both wanted to say but couldn't. So many hopes and fears.
3. During our visit, we met with his mother and father (who had not seen him for years, since he fled) to pass along gifts and greetings.
2. During our preparations, I met a classmate who escaped from Cuba to US by being smuggled in the trunk of a car during trip to Brazil.
1. When I was in business school, I had the chance to (legally) travel to Castro's Cuba for a week-long study project.
